content.body:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1717760 
little find today https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1717760
initKeyEvent exists in Gecko.

Slight inconsistency with HTMLAllCollection (https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#the-htmlallcollection-interface): The non-normative text lists a subset of elements that can have a name compared to the normative text. "Only button, form, iframe, input, map, meta, object, select, and textarea elements can have a name for the purpose of this method;" vs "The following elements are "all"-named elements: a, button, embed, form, frame, frameset, iframe, img, input, map, meta, object, select, and textarea".
(Guess which I cut & pasted into my code first.)
The normative list is correct, matches Safari and Firefox, and passes the wpt.
* The normative list is correct, matches Safari, Chrome and Firefox, and passes the wpt.

m.new_content.body: The normative list is correct, matches Safari, Chrome and Firefox, and passes the wpt.

content.body: thanks!

emilio: do you have a compat assessment for not supporting <legend style=text-align> as a way to position the legend? (gecko doesn't support it, per html spec, but chromium and webkit do) https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=880822#c5
content.formatted_body: emilio: do you have a compat assessment for not supporting <legend style=text-align> as a way to position the legend? (gecko doesn't support it, per html spec, but chromium and webkit do) https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=880822#c5

content.body: demo http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/9441

> <@zcorpan_:matrix.org> emilio: do you have a compat assessment for not supporting <legend style=text-align> as a way to position the legend? (gecko doesn't support it, per html spec, but chromium and webkit do) https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=880822#c5

I think the reason it works in Webkit / Blink is just an implementation detail. <Legend align> is a pres attr for text-align rather than a special thing
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @zcorpan_:matrix.org
emilio: do you have a compat assessment for not supporting <legend style=text-align> as a way to position the legend? (gecko doesn't support it, per html spec, but chromium and webkit do) https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=880822#c5
I think the reason it works in Webkit / Blink is just an implementation detail. is a pres attr for text-align rather than a special thing

content.body: We could implement it that way fairly easily if the spec changes, I don't think there'd be much compat impact

Domenic: If we know two documents have URLs with the same scheme/user/host/port, can we also assume they are same origin? (I know the converse is not true due to window.open() and about:blank documents)
content.formatted_body: Domenic: If we know two documents have URLs with the same scheme/user/host/port, can we also assume they are same origin? (I know the converse is not true due to window.open() and about:blank documents)

content.body: emilio: ok, I mean the opposite though, are there known compat problems for gecko for not supporting text-align as a positioning mechanism?
content.formatted_body: emilio: ok, I mean the opposite though, are there known compat problems for gecko for not supporting text-align as a positioning mechanism?

content.body: I couldn't easily find webcompat bugs on text-align in legend, but I'm not the expert on how to search for such things; karlcow might be better
content.formatted_body: I couldn't easily find webcompat bugs on text-align in legend, but I'm not the expert on how to search for such things; karlcow might be better

content.body:
> <@timothygu:matrix.org> Domenic: If we know two documents have URLs with the same scheme/user/host/port, can we also assume they are same origin? (I know the converse is not true due to window.open() and about:blank documents)

I think document.open() can change the document's URL/scheme/host/port to a cross-origin URL without changing its origin.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @timothygu:matrix.org
Domenic: If we know two documents have URLs with the same scheme/user/host/port, can we also assume they are same origin? (I know the converse is not true due to window.open() and about:blank documents)
I think document.open() can change the document's URL/scheme/host/port to a cross-origin URL without changing its origin.

content.body:
> <@zcorpan_:matrix.org> emilio: ok, I mean the opposite though, are there known compat problems for gecko for not supporting text-align as a positioning mechanism?

I don't think I've seen any
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @zcorpan_:matrix.org
emilio: ok, I mean the opposite though, are there known compat problems for gecko for not supporting text-align as a positioning mechanism?
I don't think I've seen any

content.body: also, isn't the origin of a blob url in its pathname, and not scheme/user/host/port?
similarly with about:blank inheriting origin... its not obvious from any components what the origin
* similarly with about:blank inheriting origin... its not obvious from any components what the origin is

m.new_content.body: similarly with about:blank inheriting origin... its not obvious from any components what the origin is

content.body: Yeah but they are all examples of same origin =/> similar URL
I'm asking about whether similar URL => same origin
Well for blob: URLs they all have blob: scheme, empty string host, null port, but different origins.
Thank you, that makes sense!
And you could make a cross-document iframe, document.open() it from the outside, and then they'd have the same URL but different origins.
(Although the spec for that case is still in flux...)
I didn't think you could document.open a cross-origin documentâ€¦
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/dynamic-markup-insertion.html#document-open-steps step 4
Oh true
Window.innerWidth is defined to be "zero if there is no viewport." https://drafts.csswg.org/cssom-view/#dom-window-innerwidth In what sorts of contexts is there no viewport?
Eric Portis (he/him): e.g. <iframe style="display: none"></iframe>
